awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Studying the Impact of IPv6 on Information Controls and Censorship Circumvention
awd_abstract_narration:
Deployment of the IPv6 standard has seen a rapid increase in the past decade with Google currently measuring 25-30% of their traffic being served over native IPv6 connections, 25% of all Internet-connected networks advertising IPv6 connectivity, and major mobile networks such as T-Mobile embracing the standard. Accordingly, there is an urgent need for censorship circumvention tool developers and researchers to measure how IPv6 deployments are impacting online information control systems, and how the emergence of IPv6 could enable novel circumvention techniques to augment existing tools. The overall objective in this project is to develop measurement methodologies to track IPv6-specific information control deployments and develop new circumvention strategies which leverage features of the IPv6 deployment and protocol. The research can have wide reaching near and long term impact in terms of facilitating free and open communication over the Internet. 

The project makes the following technical contributions. First, the project measures how information controls deployments are modified to handle IPv6 traffic. The project seeks to understand how IPv6 is handled by information controls deployments. To this end, the investigators explore two directions: updating existing IPv4-specific measurement techniques and platforms to make them IPv6-capable and developing new measurement techniques utilizing the IPv6 protocol to improve information controls measurement capabilities. Second, the project designs schemes that leverage the IPv6 protocol to bypass online censors in the short- and long-term. The goal is to understand how the IPv6 protocol can aid censorship circumvention. To this end, the researchers explore three directions: (1) making short-term gains against censors by leveraging IPv6 transition technologies, (2) advancing the state of Refraction Networking technologies by using IPv6, and (3) developing clean slate IPv6 based circumvention tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Deployment of the IPv6 protocol has seen a rapid increase in the past decade, with many ISPs embracing the standard. This project sought to measure how IPv6 deployments around the world are impacting online information controls systems and how novel circumvention techniques could be developed in response to IPv6 deployments.

To achieve this goal, we undertook three complementary research thrusts:

(1) We examined how IPv6 networks and information controls systems were being deployed by ISPs around the globe, with a specific focus on how these deployments varied from their IPv4 counterparts. Our studies yielded insights into the gaps that exist in IPv6 information controls infrastructure, when compared to IPv4 deployments. For example, we found that in the context of DNS-based information controls, IPv4 and IPv6 censorship rates were comparable but not identical. Notably, countries such as Iran, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Myanmar presented consistent discrepencies between their IPv4 and IPv6 deployments across multiple measurements and from multiple vantage points, indicating systemic flaws in their centrally coordinated information controls systems. Other countries such as Russia showed more varied discrepencies across networks, due to their decentralized information controls infrastructure.

(2) We devised techniques to identifiy and characterize "active probing" (i.e., unsolicited scanning traffic) from these deployments. Specifically, we used a combination of controlled and natural experiments to examine how scanners attempt to discover how ISPs allocate IPv6 addresses and the services that use them.

(3) We developed novel and augmented existing circumvention tools and measurement infrastructure with IPv6 capabilities. Toward this goal, we systematically examined how IPv4-to-IPv6 tunneling technologies could be used for circumvention and developed new methodologies for measuring DNS information controls deployments within a region without having access to vantage points within it.

Broadly, our research improved the state-of-the-art in IPv6 network measurement and IPv6 censorship circumvention. Our research resulted in peer-reviewed research publications, blog posts for the public, and updates to both information controls/network measurement infrastructure and popular circumvention software. In addition, this project supported the development of new lectures and assignments within the undergraduate Computer Science "Networking" and "Computer Security" curriculum at the University of Iowa.  

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2025
Modified by: Rishab Nithyanand

Deployment of the IPv6 protocol has seen a rapid increase in the past decade, with many ISPs embracing the standard. This project sought to measure how IPv6 deployments around the world are impacting online information controls systems and how novel circumvention techniques could be developed in response to IPv6 deployments.


To achieve this goal, we undertook three complementary research thrusts:


(1) We examined how IPv6 networks and information controls systems were being deployed by ISPs around the globe, with a specific focus on how these deployments varied from their IPv4 counterparts. Our studies yielded insights into the gaps that exist in IPv6 information controls infrastructure, when compared to IPv4 deployments. Broadly, our research improved the state-of-the-art in IPv6 network measurement and IPv6 censorship circumvention. Our research resulted in peer-reviewed research publications, blog posts for the public, and updates to both information controls/network measurement infrastructure and popular circumvention software. In addition, this project supported the development of new lectures and assignments within the undergraduate Computer Science "Networking" and "Computer Security" curriculum at the University of Iowa.
